text.b: M E M O R A N D U M

page.text: SP 14-06-19 – Site Plan to renovate building façades, reconfigure driveways and
off-street parking, and establish pet supply store (Pet Smart) within vacant unit of
shopping center at 27844-27958 Woodward Ave. (parcel nos. 25-17-429-002,
Harry & Tania Berman Co., LLC, Petitioner & Owner
The above referenced site plan is scheduled for consideration by the Planning Commission at
its meeting of June 10, 2014. Should the Planning Commission wish to consider approval of the
site plan, including all discretionary items, the Planning Department recommends the following
1. Existing driveways to Woodward Avenue shall be reconfigured as recommended by the
Engineering Department and identified on the site plan, unless alternative configurations are
determined necessary and advisable by the Planning Commission. Other improvements to
the public right-of-way shall be in accordance with the specifications and standards of the
Engineering Department, including sidewalk crossings over driveway approaches, etc.
2. The loading and unloading area proposed at the east rear façade of 27942 Woodward Ave.
(Pet Smart) shall be modified and reconfigured as determined necessary and advisable by
3. The petitioner shall prepare and submit a modified license agreement for approval by the
City Commission for all encroachments into the alley right-of-way, including additional waste
or recycling receptacles, reconfigured loading and unloading areas, etc.
4. The petitioner shall submit a revised landscaping plan for review and approval by the
Planning Department that includes all proposed as well as existing landscaping and
5. All exterior waste and recycling receptacles shall be screened in accordance with § 770-90
6. All new and/or modified exterior lighting shall comply with § 770-96 (B) of the Zoning
Ordinance and other city codes and ordinances, including being shielded or recessed and
directed downward so as not to shine on adjacent property, within maximum permitted
fixture heights, and within maximum permitted illumination levels.
7. All signage shall comply with the Sign Ordinance (Chapter 607 Signs, Article II Sign
Regulations) or receive the necessary variances from the Planning Commission. Permits for
new signage shall not be issued until all existing nonconforming signs are removed,
modified to be in compliance with required standards, or granted variances by the Planning
8. A performance bond shall be posted in an amount to be determined by the Building Official.
9. The site plan shall meet all other code and ordinance requirements, as determined by the
Building Official and City Engineer, prior to issuance of any building or right-of-way permits,
including, but not limited to, the Michigan Building Code and the city’s Stormwater Detention
cc: Howard Friedlander, Harry & Tania Berman Co., LLC
Kevin P. Doyle, RA, LEED AP, Harley Ellis Devereaux

i.b: It is recommended that the petitioner or a representative attend the June 10, 2014 Planning Commission
meeting. The meeting starts at 7:30 p.m. in the City Commission Chambers on the 3rd floor of City Hall.

Woodward Commercial Center Driveway Evaluation FINAL Memo 5-2-14
This memorandum presents the results of a site access evaluation for the Woodward Commercial Center in
the City of Royal Oak, Michigan. The project site is located on the southeast corner of Woodward Avenue (M-
1) and Catalpa Drive with one driveway to Catalpa Drive and five driveways to M-1. The commercial center is
proposing improvements to the site which include minor modifications to the on-site parking layout and the
reconstruction of the existing drive approaches. The proposed access plan includes converting the four full
movement driveways on M-1 to directional ingress or egress only driveways. Additionally, a new egress only
driveway is proposed on Catalpa Drive approximately 100 feet west of the existing driveway.
As the site is operational and currently generates vehicle trips, the proposed site modifications will not add
additional traffic volumes to the adjacent roadways. Therefore, there will be no impact to existing intersection
Levels of Service (LOS), vehicle delays, or vehicle queues on the adjacent road network. The purpose of this
study is to evaluate vehicle queues from the signalized intersection of M-1 & Catalpa Drive with respect to the
, 2014 Fleis & VandenBrink Engineering (F&V) subconsultant Traffic Data Collection,
Inc. (TDC) collected weekday AM (7:00 AM to 9:00 AM) and PM (4:00 PM to 6:00 PM) peak period turning
movement counts at the intersection of M-1 & Catalpa Drive. F&V also collected an inventory of existing lane
use and traffic controls and obtained existing traffic signal timing information from the Michigan Department of
Transportation (MDOT). The applicable data referenced in this memorandum are attached.
Existing site access currently includes four full-movement driveways to M-1, one ingress only driveway to M-
1, and a full-movement driveway to Catalpa Drive. The proposed access on M-1 includes converting the four
full-movement driveways to M-1 into ingress and egress only driveways. The proposed access plan is an
improvement with respect to access management principles. Additionally, the conversion of the southern and
driveways between the two buildings to ingress only will prohibit vehicles from trying to go straight across M-1
into the aligned northbound to southbound cross over.
Woodward Commercial Center Driveway Evaluation FINAL Memo 5-2-14
Vehicle queue lengths from the signalized intersection of M-1 & Catalpa Drive were calculated and evaluated
with respect to the proposed driveway to Catalpa Drive using Synchro and SimTraffic (Version 8) traffic
analysis software. This analysis was based on the existing lane use and traffic control, the existing traffic
volumes, and the proposed site access plan. On Catalpa Drive the westbound through queue length is critical
for egress left turns from the proposed site driveway. The queue length calculations are based on Synchro
and SimTraffic simulations and are shown in Table 1.
The results of the queue evaluation indicate that the 95
westbound vehicle queue length would occasionally
block the proposed driveway to Catalpa Drive during both peak periods. However, observation of the
SimTraffic network simulations indicates that occurrence of the 95
percentile queue length will be infrequent
and significant conflict between this queue and site traffic will be limited.
The results of this access evaluation are as follows:
1. The proposed access plan is an improvement with respect to access management principles and as
compared to the existing site access.
2. Vehicle queue lengths on Catalpa Drive will periodically block the proposed site driveway; however,
this occurrence will be infrequent and significant conflict between this queue and site traffic will be
Any questions related to this memorandum, study, analyses, and results should be addressed to Fleis &

ped. signals all quadrants, no push buttons. No turn on red signed for WB Catalpa at Woodwars Ave.
